lessons.title: So far
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far, we've joined tables based on common columns having the same name, like id here.

Make sure to pick id, followed by id.

lessons.title: Comparable
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also join on differently-named columns, as long as their values are comparable.

To get rid of same-name columns, we renamed id in enrolled to student_id.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's give it a thought. Why is the id column in student comparable to student_id in enrolled?

Because they store the same kind of data, despite the different column namesBecause they're both the first column in their table

Because they store the same kind of data, despite the different column names.

lessons.title: Different names
lessons.interactiveContent:
Since id and student_id store comparable data, we can use them as the join columns.

Make sure to pick id, followed by enrolled.student_id.

lessons.title: Same type
lessons.interactiveContent:
For two columns to be comparable, they have to be of the same type, like id and student_id, which store numbers.

Make sure to pick ON student.id, followed by =, and finally enrolled.student_id.

lessons.title: Different types
lessons.interactiveContent:
Joining on columns with a different type, like id and class gives no results.

Make sure to type class.

lessons.title: Question: Comparable
lessons.interactiveContent:
Can we join tables if all their columns have different names?

Yes, we can also join on differently-named columnsNo, since we need at least one column with the same name

Yes, we can also join on differently-named columns.

lessons.title: Question: Different names
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which columns can we join these tables on?

artist.id and album.artist_idartist.name and album.artist

artist.id and album.artist_id.

lessons.title: Question: Different types
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is it not a good idea to join on columns with different data types?

Because there'll be no match and we won't get any resultsBecause the query will delete all the data in both tables

Because there'll be no match and we won't get any results.

lessons.title: Example: Different names
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make sure to match table rows when the artist.id equals the album table's artist_id.

Make sure to type album.artist_id.

lessons.title: Example: Different types
lessons.interactiveContent:
Join on the different-type columns artist.name and album.artist_id and notice that we get no results.

Make sure to pick . followed by name and then =, album, ., artist_id.

lessons.title: Big result table
lessons.interactiveContent:
The result table of an INNER JOIN has the columns of both tables combined, four in our case.

Make sure to type INNER JOIN.

lessons.title: Only some columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can simplify the result table by selecting only some columns, like student.name and then enrolled.class.

Make sure to pick student.name, followed by ,, and finally enrolled.class.

lessons.title: Only some columns 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
This query selects name from students and class from enrolled, wherever student.id matches enrolled.student_id.

Make sure to pick SELECT student.name, followed by enrolled.class and then student.id =, enrolled.student_id.

lessons.title: Only some columns 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Notice that when selecting columns in a multi-table query, we have to access them by their table name, like with student.name.

Make sure to type student.name.

lessons.title: Question: Big result table
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many columns will the result table have?

Four, since each table has two columns and we're selecting all of them with *Three, since only one of the columns we join on will appear

Four, since each table has two columns and we're selecting all of them with *.

lessons.title: Question: Only some columns 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query do?

It selects the artist name and album title of rows where the id matches the artist_idIt selects the artist name and album title from the artist table

It selects the artist name and album title of rows where the id matches the artist_id.

lessons.title: Question: Only some columns 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this query?

It should access columns by their table name when selecting themIt's missing a SELECT statement

It should access columns by their table name when selecting them.

lessons.title: Example: Only some columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select name from artist, and then title from album.

Make sure to pick artist followed by . and then name,, album, ., title.

lessons.title: Example: Only some columns 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the artist id with artist.id. Don't forget to add a comma ,.

Make sure to type artist.id,.

lessons.title: Aliasing selected columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use aliasing to rename selected columns. Change student.name with AS and the alias student.

Make sure to type AS student.

lessons.title: Aliasing tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also alias tables inside the query to avoid repeatedly writing long table names. Rename student to s and enrolled to e.

Make sure to pick student AS s, followed by AS, and finally e.

lessons.title: Using table aliases
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we alias tables, we must use these aliases everywhere in the query. Code s for student and e for enrolled in the condition.

Make sure to pick s, followed by e.

lessons.title: Using table aliases 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
We also have to use the table aliases when selecting specific columns, like with s.name to access the name column from student.

Make sure to type s.name.

lessons.title: Using table aliases 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Aliasing a table like with student AS s doesn't change the original. It just helps us write shorter queries and get the same result.

Make sure to type student AS s.

lessons.title: Question: Aliasing selected columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
How will the two columns in the result table be called?

artist and albumartist.name and album.title

artist and album.

lessons.title: Question: Aliasing tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why would we want to alias tables?

To not have to write long table names everywhere in the queryTo change the column names in the result table

To not have to write long table names everywhere in the query.

lessons.title: Question: Using table aliases
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this query?

It should also use the table aliases art and alb when accessing columnsIt's missing an INNER JOIN statement

It should also use the table aliases art and alb when accessing columns.

lessons.title: Question: Using table aliases 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this query?

There's nothing wrong with the queryIt isn't using the table aliases when accessing columns in the condition

There's nothing wrong with the query.

lessons.title: Question: Using table aliases 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Does aliasing a table change its name in the database?

No, the alias only exists within that specific queryYes, aliasing renames the table in the database

No, the alias only exists within that specific query.

lessons.title: Example: Aliasing selected columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the album table's title under the alias album.

Make sure to type album.title AS album.

lessons.title: Example: Aliasing tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select all fields from the artist table aliased as art joined with the album table aliased as alb.

Make sure to pick FROM followed by artist and then AS, art, INNER JOIN, album AS alb.

lessons.title: Example: Using table aliases
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the alias to access the artist table's id column.

Make sure to type art.id.

lessons.title: Example: Using table aliases 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the table aliases to select the name column from artist and title from album.

Make sure to pick art followed by . and then alb, ..
